Package dsa_assignment4

Class CsvUtils

java.lang.Object
dsa_assignment4.CsvUtils
public class CsvUtils
extends java.lang.Object
A class containing only static methods to externally sort simplified CSV files

    • copyCsv

      public static boolean copyCsv​(java.nio.file.Path fromPath, java.nio.file.Path toPath) throws java.lang.Exception
      A sample method to show the basic mechanism for reading and writing CSV files using the CsvFormatter class. This just copies the input file to the output file with no changes. However it has to make sure that the output file is created with the correct CSV header.
      Parameters:
      fromPath - The path of the CSV file to read from
      toPath - The path of the CSV file to write to
      Returns:
      true if it manages to complete without throwing exceptions: if this were an empty method that you had to implement as part of this assignment, you should leave the return value as false until you had completed it to avoid unnecessary testing of an unimplemented method
      Throws:
      java.lang.Exception - if anything goes wrong, e.g. if you can't open either file, can't read from the fromPath file, can't write to the toPath file, if the from file does not match the requirements of the simplified CSV file format, etc.

    • splitSortCsv

      public static java.nio.file.Path[] splitSortCsv​(java.nio.file.Path fromPath, java.lang.String columnName, int numRowLimit) throws java.lang.Exception
      Split an (unordered) CSV file into separate smaller CSV files (runs) containing sorted runs of row, where the rows are sorted in ascending order of the column identified by the columnName parameter. This is intended to be the first stage of a merge sort which produces sorted runs that can then be merged together.

      This code should work on truly huge files: far larger than we can hold in memory at the same time. To simulate this without using huge files, we impose a limit on the size of each run, given by the numRowLimit parameter. Further, NO internal sort algorithms should be used: e.g. Arrays.sort, Collections.sort, SortedList etc. Instead a PriorityQueue must be used to generate the sorted runs: Have a loop. Inside the loop, read in a maximum of numRowLimit rows from the input and insert them into the priority queue and then extract them in order and write them out to a new split file.

      The split file should be a sibling (i.e. in the same directory) as the input file and have a name which is "temp_00000_" followed by the name of the input file, where the "00000" is replace by a sequence number: "00000" for the first split file, "00001" for the second etc.

      Parameters:
      fromPath - The relative path where the input file is
      columnName - The header name of the column used for sorting
      numRowLimit - The maximum number of value rows (not including the header row) that can be written into each split file
      Returns:
      the Path[] of paths for the full list of split files created
      Throws:
      java.lang.Exception - If anything goes wrong with opening, reading or writing the files, or if the input file does not match the simplified CSV requirements.

    • mergePairCsv

      public static boolean mergePairCsv​(java.nio.file.Path file1Path, java.nio.file.Path file2Path, java.lang.String columnName, java.nio.file.Path outputPath) throws java.lang.Exception
      Merge two ordered input CSV files into a single ordered output CSV file The two input CSV files must be already ordered on the column specified by columnName and must have the same CSV format (same number of columns, same headers in the same order) The output file must similarly be of the same CSV format and ordered on the same column.
      Parameters:
      file1Path - The relative path of the first input file
      file2Path - The relative path of the second input file
      columnName - The column to order the output file on and, upon which, both input files are ordered
      outputPath - The relative path of the output file
      Returns:
      true, if this method has been implemented. If it has not yet been implemented, then it returns false and this is used to cause the unit test to fail early without doing a lot of unnecessary work
      Throws:
      java.lang.Exception - If anything goes wrong with opening, reading or writing the files, or if the input files do not match the simplified CSV requirements or have different CSV formats

    • mergeListCsv

      public static boolean mergeListCsv​(java.nio.file.Path[] pathList, java.lang.String columnName, java.nio.file.Path outputPath) throws java.lang.Exception
      Merge a list of ordered input CSV files into a single ordered output CSV file

      The input CSV files must be already ordered on the column specified by columnName and must have the same CSV format (same number of columns, same headers in the same order) The output file must similarly be of the same CSV format and ordered on the same column.

      This method should merge all the files together by calling mergePairCsv(...) on pairs of files, starting with those on pathList, producing larger and larger intermediate file until the last pair-wise merge is used to produce the output file.

      Parameters:
      pathList - An array of relative paths of the input files
      columnName - The column to order the output file on and, upon which, both input files are ordered
      outputPath - The relative path of the output file
      Returns:
      true, if this method has been implemented. If it has not yet been implemented, then it returns false and this is used to cause the unit test to fail early without doing a lot of unnecessary work
      Throws:
      java.lang.Exception - If anything goes wrong with opening, reading or writing the files, or if the input files do not match the simplified CSV requirements or have different CSV formats
